metadata.dc:title: Tephrabase
metadata.dc:creator: Anthony Newton
metadata.dc:description: Tephrabase contains details of tephra layers at over 1000 sites in Europe and over 400 of these are in Iceland. The Icelandic tephra layers range from the early Holocene period to the most recent eruptions. Many of the tephra layers erupted since the settlement of Iceland in the 9th century have been precisely dated from ice core dating and using historical sources. This has produced an unparalleled chronology which can be used date archaeological sites and palaeoenvironmental records, enabling correlations between the two and rates of environmental change to be studied.

dcterms:hasPart.title: Teph Tephra Tephraname
dcterms:hasPart.description: The name of the tephra (volcanic ash) layer. Tephra is composed of any particulate material transported through the air during an eruption and can be composed of volcanic glass, minerals, rock fragments.
